content.title: Pericarditis
content.summary: Inflammation of the pericardium presenting with pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub, diffuse ST elevation with PR depression, and pericardial effusion, most commonly viral in etiology and treated with NSAIDs and colchicine
key_points: Diagnosis requires 2 of 4 criteria: pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub, diffuse ST elevation/PR depression, new pericardial effusion
Most cases are idiopathic or viral (coxsackie, echovirus, adenovirus)
ECG shows diffuse ST elevation (concave up) with PR depression; Spodick's sign (downsloping TP segment)
Pericardial friction rub is pathognomonic (scratchy, 3-component sound at left sternal border)
First-line treatment: NSAID (ibuprofen or ASA) + colchicine for 3 months
Colchicine reduces recurrence by 50% - MUST be included in initial therapy
Avoid corticosteroids (increase recurrence risk) except in specific situations
High-risk features: fever >38°C, large effusion, tamponade, immunosuppression

statement.text: Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium characterized by pleuritic chest pain relieved by sitting forward, pericardial friction rub, diffuse ST elevation with PR depression on ECG, and pericardial effusion. Most cases are idiopathic (presumed viral). First-line treatment is NSAIDs plus colchicine; corticosteroids increase recurrence and should be avoided unless contraindications to first-line therapy exist. Colchicine for 3 months significantly reduces recurrence risk.
statement.formal: Pericarditis diagnosis = ≥2 of 4: (1) Pleuritic chest pain + (2) Pericardial rub + (3) ST elevation/PR depression + (4) Pericardial effusion

explanation.intuition: The pericardium is a double-layered sac surrounding the heart. When inflamed, the two layers rub against each other (creating the friction rub) and the inflammation irritates adjacent structures. Pain worsens with breathing (pleuritic) because lung expansion moves the inflamed pericardium. Sitting forward reduces heart contact with the pericardium, relieving pain. The ECG changes reflect generalized pericardial inflammation rather than localized ischemia.
explanation.key_insight: The key distinguishing features from STEMI are: (1) Diffuse ST elevation (not territorial distribution), (2) PR depression (opposite of STEMI), (3) Absence of reciprocal ST changes, (4) Pain pleuritic and positional. The ECG may show Spodick's sign (downsloping TP segment). Troponin elevation can occur in myopericarditis but regional wall motion will be preserved.
explanation.technical_details: ECG changes evolve through 4 stages: Stage 1 (acute) - diffuse ST elevation, PR depression; Stage 2 (days) - ST normalizes; Stage 3 - diffuse T-wave inversions; Stage 4 - ECG normalizes. The J-point to T-wave amplitude ratio >0.25 in V6 suggests pericarditis over early repolarization. Echocardiography may show pericardial effusion but is often normal in uncomplicated acute pericarditis.

definitions_glossary.pericarditis: Inflammation of the pericardium presenting with chest pain, friction rub, ECG changes, and/or effusion
definitions_glossary.pericardium: Double-layered sac surrounding the heart, consisting of fibrous outer layer and serous inner layers
definitions_glossary.pleuritic_chest_pain: Sharp chest pain worsening with inspiration and coughing; characteristic of pericardial inflammation
definitions_glossary.pericardial_friction_rub: High-pitched scratchy sound at left sternal border; may have 3 components (atrial systole, ventricular systole, early diastole)
definitions_glossary.diffuse_st_elevation: ST elevation in multiple leads not corresponding to a single coronary territory
definitions_glossary.pr_depression: ECG finding of depressed PR segment; highly specific for pericarditis
definitions_glossary.spodick_sign: Downsloping of the TP segment on ECG; suggestive of pericarditis
definitions_glossary.pericardial_effusion: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space; may be seen on echocardiography
definitions_glossary.cardiac_tamponade: Life-threatening compression of the heart by pericardial fluid causing obstructive shock
definitions_glossary.myopericarditis: Pericarditis with myocardial involvement evidenced by troponin elevation or wall motion abnormality
definitions_glossary.constrictive_pericarditis: Chronic pericardial thickening causing impaired diastolic filling; late complication
definitions_glossary.colchicine: Anti-inflammatory medication that reduces pericarditis recurrence by inhibiting microtubule assembly
definitions_glossary.recurrent_pericarditis: Symptom recurrence after ≥4-6 weeks symptom-free interval; affects 15-30% of patients
definitions_glossary.uremic_pericarditis: Pericarditis in patients with ESRD; indication for urgent dialysis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Pericardial inflammation results from infection, autoimmunity, metabolic derangements, or malignancy. Viral infection is most common, triggering inflammatory cell infiltration and fibrin deposition on pericardial surfaces. The inflamed visceral and parietal pericardium rub together, producing the characteristic friction rub. Inflammation of adjacent diaphragmatic and mediastinal pleura explains pleuritic pain. Exudation of inflammatory fluid produces pericardial effusion.
cellular_events: Viral infection or immune activation triggers inflammatory response
Neutrophils and macrophages infiltrate pericardial tissue
Cytokine release (IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α) perpetuates inflammation

etiologies.idiopathic_viral: 80-90% of cases; coxsackie, echovirus, adenovirus, CMV, EBV, HIV
etiologies.bacterial: Rare; tuberculosis (important in endemic areas), purulent pericarditis
etiologies.autoimmune: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, Dressler syndrome (post-MI)
etiologies.malignancy: Lung, breast cancer, lymphoma; often causes large effusion

requires_2_of_4: Pleuritic chest pain (sharp, worsens with inspiration, improves sitting forward)
ECG changes (diffuse ST elevation and/or PR depression)

ecg_findings.stage_1_acute: Diffuse concave ST elevation, PR depression (especially lead II), Spodick's sign
ecg_findings.stage_2: ST segments normalize, T waves flatten

laboratory.inflammatory_markers: Elevated CRP, ESR; useful for monitoring
laboratory.troponin: May be elevated in myopericarditis; does not change management

imaging.echocardiography: May show pericardial effusion; often normal in uncomplicated cases
imaging.chest_xray: Usually normal; enlarged cardiac silhouette if large effusion
imaging.cardiac_mri: Pericardial enhancement on late gadolinium; useful for recurrent or atypical cases

major: Failure to respond to NSAIDs within 1 week

nsaids.ibuprofen: 600-800 mg TID for 1-2 weeks, taper over 2-4 weeks
nsaids.aspirin: 750-1000 mg TID; preferred in post-MI pericarditis

colchicine.dose: 0.5 mg BID (or 0.5 mg daily if <70 kg or intolerant)
colchicine.duration: 3 months for first episode; 6 months for recurrence
colchicine.evidence: COPE, CORE, CORP trials: reduces recurrence by ~50%

activity_restriction.general: Limit strenuous activity until symptoms resolve and CRP normalizes
activity_restriction.athletes: No competitive sports for 3 months minimum

corticosteroids.indication: Only if NSAID contraindicated (pregnancy, renal failure) or refractory
corticosteroids.caution: Increases recurrence rate; use low dose, slow taper
corticosteroids.dose: Prednisone 0.25-0.5 mg/kg/day, slow taper over months

refractory_recurrent.anakinra: IL-1 receptor antagonist; for colchicine-resistant recurrent pericarditis

specific_etiologies.malignant: Treat underlying malignancy, pericardiocentesis if needed

definition.@value: Inflammation of the pericardium characterized by pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub, ECG changes, and pericardial effusion

skos.scopeNote: Covers acute and recurrent pericarditis diagnosis and treatment; excludes constrictive pericarditis and cardiac tamponade as separate topics
skos.example: A 28-year-old male with sharp chest pain worsening with inspiration, relieved by sitting forward; ECG shows diffuse ST elevation with PR depression; friction rub on exam; treated with ibuprofen and colchicine

learning_objectives: Apply diagnostic criteria for acute pericarditis
Distinguish pericarditis from STEMI based on ECG findings
Prescribe appropriate first-line therapy with NSAIDs and colchicine
Identify high-risk features warranting hospitalization or additional workup
Recognize complications including tamponade and constrictive pericarditis
clinical_pearls: 2 of 4 criteria needed: pleuritic pain, friction rub, ECG changes, effusion
Diffuse ST elevation + PR depression (especially lead II vs aVR) = pericarditis, not STEMI
ALWAYS add colchicine to NSAIDs - reduces recurrence by 50%
AVOID steroids if possible - increase recurrence; reserve for contraindications to NSAIDs
Friction rub is pathognomonic but evanescent - may come and go
Post-MI pericarditis (Dressler): use aspirin instead of ibuprofen
Uremic pericarditis = indication for dialysis, not NSAIDs

board_yield.usmle_step2: Very High - diagnosis, ECG interpretation, treatment

common_misconceptions: All ST elevation is STEMI (false - pericarditis causes diffuse ST elevation without reciprocal changes)
Troponin elevation means STEMI (false - myopericarditis causes troponin rise with preserved wall motion)
Steroids are first-line for pericarditis (false - increase recurrence; NSAIDs + colchicine first)
Pericarditis always causes effusion (false - effusion present in only ~60% of cases)
